0.text:
We start off in life being very interested
in pleasure and fun. In our earliest years,

6.text:
we do little but hunt out situations that
will amuse us, pursuing our hedonistic goals

11.text:
with the help of puddles, crayons, balls,
teddies, computers and bits and pieces we

15.text:
find in the kitchen drawers. As soon as anything
gets frustrating or boring, we simply give

20.text:
up and go in search of new sources of enjoyment
– and no one appears to mind very much.

25.text:
Then, all of a sudden at the age of 5 or 6,
we are introduced to a terrifying new reality:

31.text:
the Rule of Duty. This states that there are
some things, indeed many things, that we must

37.text:
do not because we like or see the point of
them, but because other people, very intimidating

42.text:
authoritative people who may be almost three
times our size, expect us to do them – in

48.text:
order, so the big people sternly explain,
that we’ll be able to earn money, buy a

52.text:
house and go on holiday about 30 years from
now. It sounds pretty important – sort of.

58.text:
Even when we’re home and start crying and
tell our parents that we just don’t want

63.text:
to do the essay for tomorrow, they may take
the side of Duty; and speak to us with anger

68.text:
and impatience – beneath which there is
simply a lot of fear – about how people

72.text:
who can’t complete a simple homework assignment
on volcanoes (and want to build a treehouse

77.text:
instead) will never survive in the adult world.
Questions of what we actually enjoy doing,

83.text:
what gives us pleasure, still occasionally
matter in childhood, but only a bit. They

89.text:
become matters increasingly set aside from
the day-to-day world of study, reserved for

94.text:
holidays and weekends. A basic distinction
takes hold: pleasure is for hobbies, pain

100.text:
is for work. It’s no wonder that by the
time we finish university, this dichotomy

105.text:
is so entrenched, we usually can’t conceive
of asking ourselves too vigorously what we

109.text:
might in our hearts want to do with our lives;
what it might be fun to do with the years

114.text:
that remain. It’s not the way we’ve learnt
to think. The rule of duty has been the governing

119.text:
ideology for 80% of our time on earth – and
it’s become our second nature. We are convinced

125.text:
that a good job is meant to be substantially
dull, irksome and annoying. Why else would

130.text:
someone pay us to do it? The dutiful way of
thinking has such high prestige, because it

136.text:
sounds like a road to safety in a competitive
and alarmingly expensive world. But the Rule

141.text:
of Duty is actually no guarantee of true security.
Once we’ve finished our education, it in

148.text:
fact emerges as a sheer liability masquerading
as a virtue. Duty grows positively dangerous.

155.text:
The reasons are two-fold. Firstly, because
success in the modern economy will generally

160.text:
only go to those who can bring extraordinary
dedication and imagination to their labours

166.text:
– and this is only possible when one is,
to a large extent, having fun.

171.text:
motivated are we capable of generating the
very high levels of energy and brainpower

176.text:
necessary to stand out from the competition.
Work that has been produced merely out of duty will be limp and

183.text:
lacking next to that done out of love. The
other thing that happens when our work is

188.text:
informed by our own sense of pleasure is that
we get more insightful about the pleasures

192.text:
of others – that is, of the clients and
customers a business relies upon. We can best

197.text:
please our audiences when we have mobilised
our own feelings of enjoyment. In other words,

204.text:
pleasure isn’t the opposite of work; it’s
a key ingredient of successful work. Yet we

210.text:
have to recognise that asking ourselves what
we might really want to do – without any

215.text:
immediate or primary consideration for money
or reputation – goes against our every,

220.text:
educationally-embedded assumption about what
could possibly keep us safe – and is therefore

225.text:
rather scary. It takes immense insight and
maturity to stick with the truth: that we

230.text:
will best serve others – and can make our
own greatest contribution to society – when

236.text:
we bring the most imaginative and most authentically
personal sides of our nature into our work.

243.text:
Duty can guarantee us a basic income. Only
sincere, pleasure-led work can generate sizeable

249.text:
success. When people are suffering under the
rule of duty, it can be helpful to take a

254.text:
morbid turn and ask them to imagine what they
might think of their lives from the vantage

259.text:
point of their deathbeds. The thought of death
may usefully detach us from prevailing fears

265.text:
of what others think. The prospect of the
end reminds us of an imperative higher still

270.text:
than a duty to society: a duty to ourselves,
to our talents, to our interests and our passions.

277.text:
The death-bed point of view can spur us to
perceive the hidden recklessness and danger
